text: This is so good. My experience with the SMT series so far is just SMT I, IV, and the Persona series (2 through 5), but maybe I should definitely give this game a look. The music alone is amazing, and that's why I fell in love with SMT in the first place.
author: That Gaming Author

text:
That Gaming Author I haven’t actually played any SMT games, but I watched a let’s play of both games. I’d think it’s worth a try because of the Mantra system. It lets you build a character into whatever you really want. Have a healer that you think would be better suited as a damage mage or even a physical tank? You can do that. This is particularly true of DDS2’s Mantra system because it uses a hex grid instead of DDS1’s more linear system. The hex grid lets you access later stages of certain Mantra paths without taking the earlier ones, provided you plan your route properly. You also need to surround certain Mantras to unlock them, but you can partially surround it with multiple characters and it will work, giving a very interesting party dynamic. That alone seems like it would be worth any RPG nut’s time.

Also, you know, there’s the fact that you turn into demons and fucking eat other demons.

text: Not exactly.... difficulty wise, hitoshura still the hardest. Satan have more HP but if you follow the pattern of his move you still can beat him. Hitoshura on the other hand, have less HP than satan and still can learn the pattern of his move but what makes him harder is the RNG on the battle with him. When he summon pixie, you better pray RNG god is on your side that one of your party is asleep, or Gaea Rage gonna wipe your party.

text: PS3 was harder than PS2 to program so these delays have caused many in this current gen. I won't say PS2 was easy either, because many developers in the West complain about the exotic architecture like Oddworld Inhabitants. But to say japanese developers don't fear complex architecture is a lie. I wonder why we haven't seen any games from Konami this gen except Metal Gear Solid. The problem with PS3 compared to PS2 and PS1 is that it didn't allowed mid budget games on PS3.

text: @Tinhh God is the origin, all data comes from god and to god it returns. During an experiment to comunicate with God, Sera saw something that led her to inmense sadness, and when God felt that sadness his data got corrupted, making the Sun lethal to earth. The point of the fight was not to defeat him, they wanted to calm him so that Earth could be saved, and somehow from the battle Seraph would reach enlightment, making God recover his faith in humankind as he had been shown mankind´s potential
author: buntado6

text: @popimpi The karma temple (or should we say Society) is no god, they wanted to copy God power, but screwed up the entire earth in the process. God isnt a very Personal deity to say the least, he actually started damaging the Earth when he felt Sera´s sadness during an experiment to communicate with God, and then all the data of the sun started to corrupt (its complicated...). The point is that they are not figthing to defeat God (he is not the douche of other SMTs, he doesnt have a personality)

text:
Not really. Atlus doesn't really make that many sequels. Their main series only has three titles, damnit.  The rest are spinoffs. 

I dunno, there's nothing more to add to DDS. The ending was round, perfect and tied up all the loose ends. There isn't anything else to add. 

Though, a game that adopts the Mantra system WOULD be great - probably one of the best aspects of DDS.

text: Well, alternate universe are always welcomed, for all I care. It could take place like many many years after the events of the first two games, or something. That'll be nice, don't you think?
author: Euclidean Alexis

text:
No. Digital Devil Saga 2's ending wrapped everything up nicely.

If they were to make a DDS3, it would have to take place in an alternate universe, with different characters. Otherwise they'd probably ruin the plot of the first two.
